glosses: Derives names of tools from verbs or nouns.

examples.text: süz- (“to strain, to filter”) + -geç → süzgeç (“filter, sieve”)
kıs- (“to pinch, to tighten”) + -kaç → kıskaç (“clamp, pincers, claw”)

glosses: In rare cases derives adjectives from verbs, of inclination or habit.

examples.text: utan- (“to be ashamed, to be shy”) + -gaç → utangaç (“shy, timid”)
üşen- (“to feel too lazy (to do something)”) + -geç → üşengeç (“lazy, lethargic”)
gül- (“to smile, to laugh”) + -eç → güleç (“smiling often, habitually”)

glosses: Derives various nouns from verbs or other nouns.

examples.text: sür- (“to drive, to last”) + -eç → süreç (“process, continuum”)
kaya (“stone, boulder”) + -(a)ç → kayaç (“rock(any naturally occurring solid mass or aggregate of minerals)”)
tümle- (“to complete, to complement”) + -(e)ç → tümleç (“object in a sentence”)

etymology: Inherited from Ottoman Turkish ـكچ (-gaç, -geç) and sometimes ـكج (-gac, -gec), from Proto-Turkic *-gač, *-geč. In many cases in Modern Turkish the "g" falls off and the suffix presents as -aç/-eç.
